grant_details.title: Training Future Leaders in Aging Research
grant_details.abstract: Research training is crucial for medical students because they need to observe and experience how modest contributions in the field of aging research interventions can bring about profound changes and can advance health care delivery and improve quality of life for older adults and their caregivers. We believe that participation of medical student trainees in a highly structured and mentored training program in aging research provides a positive introduction to the field and will lead many to leadership careers as clinician-scientists, assume academic leadership positions and serve as tireless advocates for older adults' overall well-being and care.

grant_details.title: Medical Student Training in Aging Research (MSTAR) Program
grant_details.abstract: While the U.S. population of adults age 65 and over is predicted to double from 35 million in 2000 to 70 million by 2030, the number of physicians with training in aging research is declining. In a parallel, the aging population's diversity is increasing while the proportion of physicians from underrepresented or disadvantaged backgrounds entering careers in aging research is insufficient to meet society's needs. A program that stimulates and excites the interest of a cadre of culturally and ethnically diverse medical students to choose careers in aging research is critically needed.

grant_details.title: Training Medical Students in NIDDK Research
grant_details.abstract: Project Narrative The mandate of NIDDK is to reduce the disease burden of diabetes and other hormonal diseases, obesity, kidney and gastro-intestinal and liver diseases in the US and the world at large. We need to provide the scientific manpower to lead this effort and this proposal aims to enhance the pipeline by interesting medical students to do research in these fields. In the past 4 years we have supported 51 students in laboratories of successful scientists who investigate the nature and treatment of these diseases.

grant_details.title: Short-Term Research Training Program in NIDDK Mission Areas
grant_details.abstract: The proposed University of Illinois Short-Term Research Training Program (SRTP) will provide first year medical students with a 10-week mentored research experience in the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases (NIDDK) mission areas including, kidney, urologic and hematologic diseases; digestive disease and nutrition; and diabetes, endocrinology and metabolic disease. The proposed program brings together an outstanding team of established and emerging mentors with expertise in basic/mechanistic, clinical/translational, and behavioral/community-based research spanning NIDDK mission areas. In addition to mentored research, students will participate in interactive structured curriculum focused on research methodology, responsible conduct of research, presentation skills, and career development.

grant_details.title: Short Term Aging-Related Research Program
grant_details.abstract: NARRATIVE The aim of the Short-Term Aging-related Research (STAR) Program is to provide select first year medical students at the University of Chicago Pritzker School of Medicine with a structured mentored summer research experience in aging, coupled with didactic and experiential training in the care of older adults. Through this experience, we hope to prepare and inspire the next generation of physicians to understand and improve care for older adults through scholarship & discovery.

grant_details.title: The Case Medical Student Summer Research Program (MSSRP)
grant_details.abstract: PROJECT NARRATIVE The T35 Case Medical Student Summer Research Program (MSSRP) at Case Western Reserve University School of Medicine (CWRU SoM) is designed to attract medical students to careers as physician-scientists in the mission areas of the NIDDK by providing students with a short-term research experience during the summer between their first and second year of medical school under the mentorship of highly-qualified and motivated faculty mentors. The academic institutional environment at CWRU SoM is ideal to support this program.

grant_details.title: MEDICAL STUDENT SUMMER RESEARCH PROGRAM IN HEART, LUNG AND BLOOD DISEASES (RPHLB)
grant_details.abstract: PROJECT NARRATIVE The purpose of this grant is to support meaningful summer research experiences for first year medical students that are characterized by excellence in investigation and mentorship. Our goal is to o provide the kind of profound research experiences to propel medical students to recognize the excitement and fulfillment associated with creating new knowledge that can eventually improve human health. Our long term goals is establish a foundation for physician scientist careers.

grant_details.title: Training the Next Generation of Clinician Scientist
grant_details.abstract: Narrative Clinician scientists play a critical role in the national biomedical workforce but the number of clinician scientists is at an all time low. The overall goal of this training grant is to attract talented and interested medical students and pharmacy students into careers as clinician scientists by offering students a research fellowship that includes a mentored research project in the broad areas of infectious diseases, microbiology and immunology during the summer between first and second year of professional school. The program includes seminars, professional development, training in the responsible conduct of research, training in enhancing reproducibility of research, and the opportunity for students to present their work in oral and poster format.

grant_details.abstract: The goal of Medical Student Research Program in Metabolism, Diabetes, Digestive and Kidney Diseases (MSRP-MDDK) at the University of Utah School of Medicine is to nurture and build the physician-scientist workforce of tomorrow through mentored summer research experiences and an innovative course on creative and critical thinking in the research fields of metabolism, diabetes, digestion, hematologic or kidney disease.

grant_details.abstract: This is the second renewal application of the Alpert Medical School Summer Research Program (AMSSRP). The  overall goal of the AMSSRP is to provide  12  medical students with the opportunity to have a mentored research experience annually under the guidance of Brown University faculty. Designated faculty trainers are the principal investigators for research programs focused on the molecular basis and pathology of cardiovascular, pulmonary, and blood diseases and/or disease outcomes and prevention. The current program offers 8 medical students, who have just completed their 1  year of medical school, a 9 week summer research st experience that includes a collaborative, multidisciplinary, mentored research project, didactic training, and career development activities to enhance their understanding, and give them the hands-on experience of a career as a physician-scientist. The AMSSRP is geared to expose students to the critical role played by physician-scientists in translational rese...

grant_details.title: Summer Mentoring and Research Training (SMART)
grant_details.abstract: In the changing ecosystem, we are faced with the evolving challenges of healthcare needs and inability to treat many chronic conditions, thus requiring discoveries and healthcare management strategies to improve health- related quality of life and develop cures; which are disproportionately affected by the paucity of physician scientists. Utilizing the “cells to society” multidisciplinary team-science approach, we aim to engage a diverse pool of MD students in hands-on research training and mentorship. This “Summer of Mentoring and Research Training (SMART)”, is anticipated to fill the gap that exists in the availability of physician-scientists to address the evolving global health challenges through research, discovery and awareness.

grant_details.title: Summer Research Training in Aging for Medical Students
grant_details.abstract: The Summer Research Training in Aging for Medical Students Program will accept sixteen medical students between their first and second year of medical school. The program will coordinate with the American Federation for Aging Research to allow both NYU School of Medicine students and students from other medical schools to participate. Students will have nine weeks of research training with experienced research mentors and faculty mentors who will introduce them to clinical geriatrics, didactic sessions on research methods, aging processes and geriatrics, and will be expected to present their research locally as well as at the American Geriatrics Society (AGS) annual meeting.

grant_details.title: Basic and Clinical Research Training for Medical Students
grant_details.abstract: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our T35 training program provides mentored summer research opportunities for early stage medical students with the goal of inspiring a passion for biomedical research. Through hands-on research training supplemented with didactic conferences on research and career development topics, we will introduce students to the excitement and challenges of research and encourage them to pursue careers the integrate research with clinical care.

grant_details.title: Wake Forest Short-term Research Training Program
grant_details.abstract: This training grant provides a summer research experience for medical students at Wake Forest School of Medicine with research focus on diabetes, digestive and kidney disease, obesity, and related disorders. It has the goal to inspire medical students to become involved in research during subsequent specialty training and careers as health care providers. Dedicated faculty mentors allow students a first-hand experience conducting state-of-the-art biomedical research in the context of a learning healthcare system, supplemented by didactic seminars and workshops, to communicate to medical students how clinical care and research should inform each other, with the goal of providing more benefit to patients and society.

grant_details.title: Biodefense & Infectious Diseases Short-Term Training to Increase Diversity in Biomedical Research
grant_details.abstract: NARRATIVE The landscape of biomedical research in the United States is changing, as are the composition and activities of the biomedical research workforce. With this evolution comes an increasing need to encourage talented medical students to pursue careers that will contribute to a better understanding of the factors that promote the diseases under investigation, the development of methodologies to predict and/or prevent disease progression, and the discovery of therapies that will help cure patients. The Summer Medical Research Internship (SMRI) at the University of Virginia addresses this need by providing medical student trainees with an immersive research experience within a rich allergy and infectious diseases research community that boasts strong and diverse basic science and opportunities for exposure to the practice and challenges of providing clinical care to patients. The overall goal of the SMRI is to provide our summer trainees with the knowledge, tools and motivation ...

grant_details.pi_names: DEFRANCO, DONALD B;HUGHEY, REBECCA P;KLEYMAN, THOMAS R (contact)
grant_details.abstract: The future of medical progress depends on the translation of advances from the bench to the bedside, and an interdisciplinary approach to complex problems. grant_details.title: Medical Student Summer Research Program in Infection and Immunity
grant_details.abstract: Project Narrative There is currently a shortage of medical student trainees who are entering into careers in academic medicine as physician-scientists; furthermore, diversity in the pool of physician-scientist pathway trainees fails to reflect the diversity of our communities. This training program entitled “Medical Student Summer Research Program in Infection and Immunity” aims to augment medical research-training opportunities and mentorship for a diverse pool of medical students at the University of Minnesota Medical School by taking advantage of the strength of our immunological sciences. With success in this effort, an increased and more diverse proportion of our medical student population will enter into physician-scientist training pathway residency programs.

grant_details.title: University of Miami kidney Innovative & Interdisciplinary Medical Education in Research Activities (UM-KIIMERA)
grant_details.abstract: NARRATIVE There are major challenges facing the nephrology community in the United States: the overall decrease in interest in nephrology as a specialty and the decreased interest in a career as physician scientist. Therefore, implementation of programs at earlier stages of training in areas where the interest in academic medicine is diminishing is a priority. The goal of this proposal is to engage first year medical students across the Florida state in a summer program designed to foster interest in nephrology by exposing students to basic, clinical, and translational science research opportunities.

grant_details.title: Short-Term Training Program In Biomedical Sciences
grant_details.abstract: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Indiana University Medical Student Program for Research and Scholarship at the Indiana University School of Medicine has established a pipeline for medical students to enter research intensive programs such as MD/PhD, MD/MS, or gap year programs, and more broadly to encourage them to embrace the career of physician-scientists. The purpose of this T35 renewal program is to continue to sustain this program and to support intensive research training (3 months) for 32 medical students in basic and translational research in the areas of cardiovascular disease, respiratory disease and hematopoiesis with highly trained investigators/mentors and in a stimulating environment.

grant_details.title: Short Term Research Training: Students in Health Professional Schools
grant_details.pi_names: ARONSON, PETER S.;CHAUDHRY, SARWAT I;HERZOG, ERICA L (contact)
grant_details.abstract: NIH/NIDDK Project Narrative The purpose of this training grant to provide intensive short-term training in research areas of interest to NIDDK for 30 selected pre-doctoral medical students in the most outstanding laboratories and training sites in the Yale University School of Medicine. The specific research experiences will range from fundamental molecular biology, cellular and organ physiology to applied clinical research. The program is designed to attract the most highly qualified Yale medical students into careers as physician-scientists in the biomedical sciences in areas of interest to NIDDK.

grant_details.title: Short Term Research Training:  Students in Health Professional Schools
grant_details.abstract: The purpose of this renewal is to provide intensive short-term research training for 24 selected pre-doctoral medical students in the most outstanding laboratories and training sites at the Yale School of Medicine. The specific research experiences will range from fundamental molecular biology and cellular physiology to applied clinical studies in heart, lung, blood, and sleep (HLBS) related diseases. The program is designed to attract the most highly qualified Yale medical students into careers as physician-scientists in the biomedical sciences.

grant_details.title: Short Term Training in Health Professional Schools
grant_details.abstract: Project Narrative Short Term Training in Health Professional Schools  The objective of the proposed training program is to expose medical students to biomedical research and the principles of scientific experimentation. There is a clear need for training additional physician scientists with expertise in understanding the causes of disease and the prevention and treatment of heart, lung, and blood disorders. This training program seeks to inspire more medical and students to pursue research careers and join the ranks of clinical investigators addressing human health issues.

grant_details.title: UCLA Medical Student Training in Aging Research (MSTAR) Program
grant_details.abstract: Regardless of whether they choose careers in research, medical education or clinical care, medical students who participate in aging research are more likely to pursue careers in aging. The David Geffen School of Medicine at the University of California Los Angeles (UCLA) is partnering with the University of California San Francisco School of Medicine (UCSF), and the University of Washington (UW) to seek continued support for a formal 8-12 week program of training in aging research as well as clinical exposure to aging for medical students.

grant_details.title: Training Future Leaders in Aging Research
grant_details.abstract: Research training is crucial for medical students because they need to observe and experience how modest contributions in the field of aging research interventions can bring about profound changes and can advance health care delivery and improve quality of life for older adults and their caregivers. We believe that participation of medical student trainees in a highly structured and mentored training program in aging research provides a positive introduction to the field and will lead many to leadership careers as clinician-scientists, assume academic leadership positions and serve as tireless advocates for older adults' overall well-being and care.

grant_details.title: Stanford Cardiovascular Summer Research Training Program for Medical Students
grant_details.abstract: PROJECT NARRATIVE With the rise in the impact of cardiovascular disease on US and world health, it is critical to train the next generation of physician-scientists in translational cardiovascular research. Participation in mentored research provides valuable training and increases the likelihood that medical students will continue to pursue research as part of their careers. This multidisciplinary Stanford Cardiovascular Summer Research Training Program for Medical Students is designed to train a diverse cohort of medical students in basic, clinical, translational and population level cardiovascular science, to provide them with a strong foundation of medical ethics, and to foster their development into investigators dedicated to identifying innovative solutions and capable of translating research into clinical success to combat cardiovascular disease.

grant_details.title: Medical Student Training in Aging Research (MSTAR) Program
grant_details.abstract: While the U.S. population of adults age 65 and over is predicted to double from 35 million in 2000 to 70 million by 2030, the number of physicians with training in aging research is declining. In a parallel, the aging population's diversity is increasing while the proportion of physicians from underrepresented or disadvantaged backgrounds entering careers in aging research is insufficient to meet society's needs. A program that stimulates and excites the interest of a cadre of culturally and ethnically diverse medical students to choose careers in aging research is critically needed.

grant_details.title: Training Medical Students in NIDDK Research
grant_details.abstract: Project Narrative The mandate of NIDDK is to reduce the disease burden of diabetes and other hormonal diseases, obesity, kidney and gastro-intestinal and liver diseases in the US and the world at large. We need to provide the scientific manpower to lead this effort and this proposal aims to enhance the pipeline by interesting medical students to do research in these fields. In the past 4 years we have supported 51 students in laboratories of successful scientists who investigate the nature and treatment of these diseases.

grant_details.title: Summer Research Training in Aging for Medical Students
grant_details.abstract: The Summer Research Training in Aging for Medical Students Program will accept sixteen medical students between their first and second year of medical school. The program will coordinate with the American Federation for Aging Research to allow both NYU School of Medicine students and students from other medical schools to participate. Students will have nine weeks of research training with experienced research mentors and faculty mentors who will introduce them to clinical geriatrics, didactic sessions on research methods, aging processes and geriatrics, and will be expected to present their research locally as well as at the American Geriatrics Society (AGS) annual meeting.

grant_details.pi_names: CHAUDHRY, SARWAT I (contact);HERZOG, ERICA L;TINETTI, MARY E
grant_details.abstract: The purpose of this training grant to is provide intensive short-term training in research areas of interest to NIA for 10 selected pre-doctoral medical students in the most outstanding laboratories and training sites in the Yale School of Medicine relating to aging. The specific training experiences will range from fundamental molecular biology, cellular and organ physiology to applied clinical research. The program is designed to attract the most highly qualified Yale medical students into careers as physician-scientists in the biomedical sciences in areas of interest to NIA.

grant_details.title: Short-Term Research Training Program in NIDDK Mission Areas
grant_details.abstract: The proposed University of Illinois Short-Term Research Training Program (SRTP) will provide first year medical students with a 10-week mentored research experience in the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases (NIDDK) mission areas including, kidney, urologic and hematologic diseases; digestive disease and nutrition; and diabetes, endocrinology and metabolic disease. The proposed program brings together an outstanding team of established and emerging mentors with expertise in basic/mechanistic, clinical/translational, and behavioral/community-based research spanning NIDDK mission areas. In addition to mentored research, students will participate in interactive structured curriculum focused on research methodology, responsible conduct of research, presentation skills, and career development.

grant_details.title: The Case Medical Student Summer Research Program (MSSRP)
grant_details.abstract: PROJECT NARRATIVE The T35 Case Medical Student Summer Research Program (MSSRP) at Case Western Reserve University School of Medicine (CWRU SoM) is designed to attract medical students to careers as physician-scientists in the mission areas of the NIDDK by providing students with a short-term research experience during the summer between their first and second year of medical school under the mentorship of highly-qualified and motivated faculty mentors. The academic institutional environment at CWRU SoM is ideal to support this program.

grant_details.abstract: This is the second renewal application of the Alpert Medical School Summer Research Program (AMSSRP). The  overall goal of the AMSSRP is to provide  12  medical students with the opportunity to have a mentored research experience annually under the guidance of Brown University faculty. Designated faculty trainers are the principal investigators for research programs focused on the molecular basis and pathology of cardiovascular, pulmonary, and blood diseases and/or disease outcomes and prevention. The current program offers 8 medical students, who have just completed their 1  year of medical school, a 9 week summer research st experience that includes a collaborative, multidisciplinary, mentored research project, didactic training, and career development activities to enhance their understanding, and give them the hands-on experience of a career as a physician-scientist. grant_details.title: Biodefense & Infectious Diseases Short-Term Training to Increase Diversity in Biomedical Research
grant_details.abstract: NARRATIVE The landscape of biomedical research in the United States is changing, as are the composition and activities of the biomedical research workforce. With this evolution comes an increasing need to encourage talented medical students to pursue careers that will contribute to a better understanding of the factors that promote the diseases under investigation, the development of methodologies to predict and/or prevent disease progression, and the discovery of therapies that will help cure patients. The Summer Medical Research Internship (SMRI) at the University of Virginia addresses this need by providing medical student trainees with an immersive research experience within a rich allergy and infectious diseases research community that boasts strong and diverse basic science and opportunities for exposure to the practice and challenges of providing clinical care to patients. The overall goal of the SMRI is to provide our summer trainees with the knowledge, tools and motivation ...

grant_details.title: Short Term Aging-Related Reseach Program
grant_details.abstract: Project Summary Given the aging of the population and concerns over the physician-scientist workforce, it is imperative that inculcate the next generation of physicians with the desire to understand and improve care for older adults through pursuit of scientific discovery in the basic, clinical, and social sciences. The purpose of this application is to renew support for the successful Short- Term Aging-related Research (STAR) T-35 program which has been providing summer training in basic, clinical, and social science research for Pritzker medical students to inspire and prepare them to pursue careers in aging research for the past 10 years. At graduation, our NIH T35 trainees are more likely to be an author on a research publication, be satisfied with research experiences in medical school, state that research enhanced their career goals, and 3 times more likely to report intention to pursue an academic full-time research career. The proposed program will continue to be led by Dr. ...

grant_details.title: Wake Forest Short-term Research Training Program
grant_details.abstract: This training grant provides a summer research experience for medical students at Wake Forest School of Medicine with research focus on diabetes, digestive and kidney disease, obesity, and related disorders. It has the goal to inspire medical students to become involved in research during subsequent specialty training and careers as health care providers. Dedicated faculty mentors allow students a first-hand experience conducting state-of-the-art biomedical research in the context of a learning healthcare system, supplemented by didactic seminars and workshops, to communicate to medical students how clinical care and research should inform each other, with the goal of providing more benefit to patients and society.

grant_details.title: UC Davis CTSC TL1 Administrative Supplement to Recognize Excellence in Diversity, Equity, Inclusion, and Accessibility Mentorship
grant_details.abstract: NARRATIVE The UC Davis Clinical and Translational Science Center (CTSC) NRSA Training Core (TL1) is committed to diversity. Our program has a large pool of diverse applicants and we provide established and enhanced training opportunities to ensure rigorous translational research training and integration of values of justice and equity into scientific practices. The proposed supplement will support the enrollment of additional predoctoral scholars who will have access to all TL1 educational experiences including a new coaching program characterized by one-on-one trainee-centered approach to career mentoring.

grant_details.title: Administrative Supplement to NIH-funded TL1 Training Grants
grant_details.abstract: A Vaccine for Racism: Cultivating Racial Equity Consciousness to Enhance Interdisciplinary Collaboration across the Phases of Clinical and Translational Research PROJECT NARRATIVE A lack of collective understanding on issues related to race and racism has limited dialogue and interdiscipli- nary collaboration in clinical and translational research. Applying techniques from the behavioral and social sciences, our objective for this supplement is to adapt, integrate, and evaluate a program to improve racial eq- uity consciousness in the TL-1 pre and postdoctoral career development curriculum. Our goal is to equip train- ees with the dispositions, knowledge, and skills necessary to more effectively and equitably collaborate across disciplines and become the next generation of antiracist-minded leaders in clinical and translational research.

grant_details.title: Expanding Training in Social and Behavioral Sciences Across the Georgia CTSA
grant_details.abstract: Project Narrative This TL1 administrative supplement supports the integration of core behavioral and social sciences methods training in the Georgia Clinical and Translational Science Alliance (CTSA) training programs in clinical and translational research. We will integrate core social and behavioral methods within existing curriculum, expand learning opportunities by offering new annual training workshops and monthly lectures focused on evaluation and implementation science for our TL1 Master's in Science in Clinical Research and Certificate Program in Translational Research trainees, and expand an existing network for evaluation and implementation sciences to include all four Georgia CTSA institutions. We hypothesize that such new training will lead to rigorous new clinical and translational research in applied social and behavioral sciences.

grant_details.title: Atlanta Clinical and Translational Science Institute (ACTSI) Renewal
grant_details.abstract: RELEVANCE (See instructions): Created in response to the NIH CTSA program, the Atlanta CTSI serves as a  catalyst and incubator for clinical and translational research across Georgia and with regional and national  impact. The goals are to create and accelerate clinical and translational science discovery, build  interdisciplinary research capacity, engage communities in health sciences activities, develop new research  tools and information technologies, and build the careers of clinical/translational scientists ofthe future.

grant_details.abstract: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of the University of Maryland BaltImore Life Science Discovery (UM-BILD) Accelerator is to create a new NIH Research Evaluation and Commercialization Hub (REACH) program that serves as a development engine to build the life science economy in West Baltimore and Greater Baltimore and to train one of the most diverse biomedical and entrepreneurial workforces in the US. Formed from a partnership by University of Maryland, Baltimore, the University of Maryland School of Medicine, University of Maryland, Baltimore County, Morgan State University, University of Maryland College Park, and the Maryland Innovation Initiative, UM-BILD will embrace existing partner programmatic efforts to increase biomedical workforce diversity such as the University of Maryland FIRST program. grant_details.title: The Maximizing Extubation outcomes Through Educational and Organizational Research (METEOR) Trial
grant_details.abstract: RELEVANCE Nearly one million patients per year in the United States require invasive mechanical ventilation for acute respiratory failure, a life-threatening condition. Many of those who recover to the point that their breathing tube is removed would benefit from mechanical ventilation delivered through a face mask or oxygen delivered through a high-flow nasal cannula, but these practices are currently underutilized. This clinical trial will compare innovative strategies designed to promote the use of these evidence-based practices.

grant_details.title: Impact of Culturally Aware Mentoring Interventions on Research Mentors and Graduate Training Programs
grant_details.abstract: PROJECT NARRATIVE We respond to the pressing need for graduate faculty to learn and employ inclusive, evidence-based mentoring practices by identifying intervention format, duration, and contexts where new knowledge and skills affect individual change and fuel change within departments and graduate training programs. The proposed project is relevant to public health because it is a promising new approach that advances scientific evidence on how changes in faculty mindsets and mentoring behaviors may promote practices in graduate departments, leading to a cultural shift in training environments so critical to the success of biomedical scientists from historically underrepresented groups. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to NIH goals pertaining to the Diversity Program Consortium (DPC) Hallmarks of Success related to individual and institutional factors such as quality of mentoring and institutional commitment to DPC activities known to contribute to diverse students pursuing c...

grant_details.title: Boosting Mentor Effectiveness iN Training of Research Scientists (MENTORS) Using Social Cognitive Career Theory to Support Entry of Women & Minorities into Physician-Scientist Careers
grant_details.abstract: PROJECT NARRATIVE The workforce of physician scientists persistently fails to reflect the diversity seen in both the general population and the diversity in US medical schools, with women and minorities underrepresented in the physician-scientist pipeline. In this proposal, we will conduct a randomized trial to test whether a targeted intervention based on social cognitive career theory for mentors of women and minority medical students could lead to increased research self-efficacy, research career persistence, objective measures of research productivity and judgments of scientific potential among women and minority mentees. In addition, we will explore whether mentee engagement in research experiences, as measured by Experience Sampling Method (ESM) in real-time, is a mechanism by which the effects of the intervention are mediated.

grant_details.title: Pacific Northwest Undiagnosed Diseases Network Clinical Site
grant_details.abstract: The Undiagnosed Disease Network (UDN) works with participants who have undergone a long diagnostic odyssey that has thus far not explained their medical condition. As a clinical site (CS) in the network, the Pacific Northwest (PNW) CS reviews, accepts, and evaluates participants while developing strategies to end diagnostic odysseys. This requested supplement is an application for funds for activities not originally planned. The overall goal is to make the UDN accessible to more underserved participants. With this supplement we plan to focus on underserved populations leveraging our decades old collaboration within in the WWAMI (Washington, Wyoming, Alaska, Montana, Idaho) region.

grant_details.title: Randomized ESRD Trial COmparing CBT alone VERsus with buprenorphine (RECOVER)
grant_details.abstract: PROJECT NARRATIVE The HOPE trial is testing treatments to manage chronic pain in people with kidney failure undergoing long-term hemodialysis. With this proposal, the investigators are seeking funds to develop educational materials to overcome barriers to telehealth and extend enrollment efforts to American Indian communities in New Mexico and the geographically isolated Kitsap and Olympic Peninsulas in the Pacific Northwest.

grant_details.title: The Maximizing Extubation outcomes Through Educational and Organizational Research (METEOR) Trial
grant_details.abstract: RELEVANCE Nearly one million patients per year in the United States require invasive mechanical ventilation for acute respiratory failure, a life-threatening condition. Many of those who recover to the point that their breathing tube is removed would benefit from mechanical ventilation delivered through a face mask or oxygen delivered through a high-flow nasal cannula, but these practices are currently underutilized. This clinical trial will compare innovative strategies designed to promote the use of these evidence-based practices.

grant_details.title: Boosting Mentor Effectiveness iN Training of Research Scientists (MENTORS) Using Social Cognitive Career Theory to Support Entry of Women & Minorities into Physician-Scientist Careers
grant_details.abstract: PROJECT NARRATIVE The workforce of physician scientists persistently fails to reflect the diversity seen in both the general population and the diversity in US medical schools, with women and minorities underrepresented in the physician-scientist pipeline. In this proposal, we will conduct a randomized trial to test whether a targeted intervention based on social cognitive career theory for mentors of women and minority medical students could lead to increased research self-efficacy, research career persistence, objective measures of research productivity and judgments of scientific potential among women and minority mentees. In addition, we will explore whether mentee engagement in research experiences, as measured by Experience Sampling Method (ESM) in real-time, is a mechanism by which the effects of the intervention are mediated.

grant_details.title: Optimizing a self-directed mobile mindfulness intervention for improving
grant_details.pi_names: COX, CHRISTOPHER ETHAN (contact);HOUGH, CATHERINE LEE;MOSS, MARC
grant_details.abstract: Project Narrative Millions of patients experience cardiorespiratory failure requiring treatment in an intensive care unit (ICU) each year. Afterward, they commonly suffer from serious symptoms of depression, anxiety, and post- traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) for months to years--yet have few therapies relevant to their experience. We propose testing an innovative app-based mindfulness training program to see what elements of the program work the best among patients with high levels of distress after arriving home from the hospital. This program has great promise to become a highly scalable therapy for patients' great burden of distress.

grant_details.title: Behavioral Economics and Implementation Research to Reduce Cardiovascular Risk in HIV-infected Adults
grant_details.abstract: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is a major cause of morbidity among people living with HIV (PLWH), but evidence-based statin therapy—highly effective at reducing cardiovascular risk—is under- prescribed for PLWH due to provider- and patient-level barriers. Recent studies have demonstrated that patients with HIV experience approximately a 50-100% increased risk of myocardial infarction and stroke compared to HIV-uninfected persons, and face higher risks of stroke, sudden death, and heart failure. In this study, we propose an innovative implementation strategy for reducing the risk of CVD among PLWH based on principles from the Consolidated Framework for Implementation Research (CFIR) and behavioral economics.

grant_details.title: ICOMPARE-CCC
grant_details.abstract: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: In US teaching hospitals, physicians in training care for patients under faculty supervision and are granted progressive autonomy and independence so that they may achieve independent practice upon completion of the program. While the US system of physician training is respected around the world, this multi-center national randomized controlled trial will determine how duty hours should be structured to optimize the quality of care in America's teaching hospitals as well as the competency of our future physicians.

grant_details.abstract: NARRATIVE Malaria control and prevention is challenging in Malawi; despite robust efforts, there has been little effect on parasite prevalence rates. Two new interventions (the malaria vaccine and an enhanced bed net) will be piloted, beginning in 2018. In this proposal, we describe how we will assess the effectiveness of these approaches as well as their acceptability at community level.

grant_details.pi_names: GAUSCHE, MARIANNE ;SAVER, JEFFREY L;STARKMAN, SIDNEY ;YADAV, KABIR  (contact)
grant_details.abstract: Medical and traumatic emergency conditions affecting the cardiac, respiratory, nervous, and hematologic systems collectively account for  the overwhelming preponderance of death and disability affecting Americans. The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic has brought into stark relief the importance of emergency care research to rapidly evaluate treatments, and the disproportionate burden that underserved populations suffer. It is imperative that new approaches for timely diagnosis and equitable treatment of these conditions be efficiently developed.

grant_details.title: Chicago Kidney Urology Hematology network FOR city-Wide reseArch tRaining and career Development (Chicago KUH FORWARD)
grant_details.pi_names: KLUMPP, DAVID J;LASH, JAMES P.;QUAGGIN, SUSAN E. (contact)
grant_details.abstract: Project Narrative Overall The research workforce in areas of Kidney, Urology and Hematology (KUH) needs to be strengthened in order to address pressing scientific questions and find treatments for patients affected by KUH conditions. The current proposal will create an innovative training program that will bring together pre- and postdoctoral trainees across 6 academic institutions across Chicago who will learn together about cross-cutting tools in a way that will allow them to develop a common language, apply the tools into their own research, and form sustained interdisciplinary research interests and collaborations. The results will have important implications for the KUH scientific community and for clinical care of patients with KUH conditions.

grant_details.title: Planning Activity and Nutrition Trial in Lupus to Energize and Renew
grant_details.abstract: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) affects up to 1.5 million persons in the US. Although excess mortality has decreased in SLE patients since the 1970's, substantial morbidity persists. Fatigue is the most disabling and enduring complaint in patients affected with this chronic incurable inflammatory autoimmune disease. The ramifications of fatigue are significant and include decreased quality of life, an increased risk of work disability and an associated increase in health care costs. We propose a planning grant which will develop the study protocol and intervention, educational materials, a manual of operations, and regulatory documents in preparation for a future U01 application to perform a clinical trial entitled, "Activity and Nutrition Trial in Lupus to Energize and Renew", ANTLER. The preliminary specific aims for the future U01 clinical trial (ANTLER) application include: 1. Test the effectiveness of the ANTLER intervention for SLE to decrease fatig...

grant_details.pi_names: LOPEZ-ENRIQUEZ, REYNOLD EUGENIO;ORTIZ, ANA PATRICIA;TRAVIS, ELIZABETH L;WEINER, BRAD R (contact)
grant_details.abstract: NARRATIVE STATEMENT Hispanics have an increased risk of infection-driven malignancies, including gastric cancer and HIV- and HPV- related malignancies. To address the increased risk factors and burden of infection-driven cancers that exist among Hispanic populations in the US, the Partnership for Excellence in Cancer Research strives to reduce these disparities through efforts in Cancer Research, Education, and Outreach. Partnership contributions, including the development of a pipeline of well-trained, Hispanic cancer researchers, will help build a stronger national cancer research and prevention program.

grant_details.title: UPR/MDACC: Partnership for Excellence in Cancer Research (2 of 2)
grant_details.pi_names: LOPEZ-ENRIQUEZ, REYNOLD EUGENIO;ORTIZ, ANA PATRICIA;TRAVIS, ELIZABETH L;WEINER, BRAD R (contact)
grant_details.abstract: NARRATIVE STATEMENT Hispanics have an increased risk of infection-driven malignancies, including gastric cancer and HIV- and HPV- related malignancies. To address the increased risk factors and burden of infection-driven cancers that exist among Hispanic populations in the US, the Partnership for Excellence in Cancer Research strives to reduce these disparities through efforts in Cancer Research, Education, and Outreach. Partnership contributions, including the development of a pipeline of well-trained, Hispanic cancer researchers, will help build a stronger national cancer research and prevention program.

grant_details.title: Center for Colaborative Research in Minority Health and Health Disparities
grant_details.abstract: PROJECT NARRATIVE In PR, only 5.8% of the population has been fully vaccinated, and 11% has been partially vaccinated, placing the US territory amongst the states and territories with the lowest vaccination rates. In collaboration with the University of Puerto Rico Medical Outpatient Clinic, our study "PR-COVACUPS: "Puerto Rico (PR) COVID-19 Vaccine Uptake Study" will evaluate the effectiveness of an educational toolkit intervention to maximize vaccine acceptability, uptake, and adherence. Our team is well-positioned to conduct this study which will generate critical information and measurable outcomes to reduce disparities in COVID-19 vaccine uptake among Spanish-speaking Hispanics.

grant_details.title: UPR/MDACC: Partnership for Excellence in Cancer Research (2 of 2)
grant_details.pi_names: LOPEZ-ENRIQUEZ, REYNOLD EUGENIO;ORTIZ, ANA PATRICIA;TRAVIS, ELIZABETH L;WEINER, BRAD R (contact)
grant_details.abstract: NARRATIVE STATEMENT Hispanics have an increased risk of infection-driven malignancies, including gastric cancer and HIV- and HPV- related malignancies. To address the increased risk factors and burden of infection-driven cancers that exist among Hispanic populations in the US, the Partnership for Excellence in Cancer Research strives to reduce these disparities through efforts in Cancer Research, Education, and Outreach. Partnership contributions, including the development of a pipeline of well-trained, Hispanic cancer researchers, will help build a stronger national cancer research and prevention program.

grant_details.title: UPR/MDACC: Partnership for Excellence in Cancer Research
grant_details.pi_names: BARTON, MICHELLE ANN;LOPEZ-BERESTEIN, GABRIEL ;LOPEZ-ENRIQUEZ, REYNOLD EUGENIO;TRAVIS, ELIZABETH L;WEINER, BRAD R (contact);WETTER, DAVID W
grant_details.abstract: Project Narrative The Puerto Rico Community Cancer Control Outreach Program (CCCOP), a core program focused on cancer prevention and community engagement in Puerto Rico, seeks to continue the recruitment efforts of the behavioral trial ‘¡Salud!, Por la Vida’, which aims to increase colorectal cancer (CRC) screening among non-adherent men and women older than 50 years old in Puerto Rico. Due to the detrimental effect of Hurricanes Irma and María, research efforts were disrupted during our emergency and recovery period. Support under this administrative supplement would allow us to complete the recruitment of study participants (n=371) and their respective follow-up 4 months after recruitment, which is part of the trial. Additionally, we will devote time to statistical analyses, interpretation of the findings, as well as manuscript and proposal development.

grant_details.abstract: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: The UNC-Malawi Cancer Consortium will address herpes virus-associated cancers among HIV-infected individuals in Malawi, which are major causes of death and disability. grant_details.title: Developing and Implementing a Culturally Appropriate Non-Opioid Pain Coping Skills Training Intervention for Spanish-Speaking Hispanic/Latinx Patients with Cancer Pain
grant_details.abstract: Narrative  Across all areas of pain management, Hispanic and Latinx populations have lower access to chronic pain treatments compared to others (particularly if have limited English proficiency) and inadequate access to suitable pain treatments. Were empirically validated/effective interventions (like the painTRAINER Internet- based coping skills training program) translated into a culturally appropriate Spanish language iteration and made broadly available, they undoubtedly would enhance access to and engagement in pain management programs amongst this marginalized population of patients. In collaboration with Hispanic and Latinx community organizations, community advisory boards, patient advocates, and oncology experts, we will follow a carefully designed community-engaged translation methodology to generate a new version of painTRAINER in the Spanish language that is both linguistically and culturally sensitive, and will establish the feasibility and acceptability of the newly ge...

grant_details.title: University of Buffalo Clinical and Translational Science Institute
grant_details.abstract: The University at Buffalo Clinical and Translational Science Institute (CTSI) is the coordinating center of the Buffalo Translational Consortium, which includes the region's premier research, educational and clinical institutions with influential community partners. The vision of the CTSI is to perform innovative clinical and translational research to reduce health disparities and improve the health of our community and the nation. We engage our community as research partners to create a shared environment to bring discoveries in the laboratory, clinic and community to benefit individual and public health.

grant_details.pi_names: BLACK, BERNARD S;MEURER, JOHN RICHARD;SHAKER, REZA NONE (contact)
grant_details.abstract: Project Narrative Our community is in need of better preventive measures, more accurate diagnostics and more effective and efficient therapies. We offer a novel and comprehensive mechanism to address this need through research and education. We propose to create a mutually learning ecosystem that coalesce a myriad of requisite stakeholders including health systems, research enterprises and the community in southeast Wisconsin to work in tandem towards solutions that improve the health outcomes of our citizens.

grant_details.title: University of Buffalo Clinical and Translational Science Institute
grant_details.abstract: The University at Buffalo Clinical and Translational Science Institute (CTSI) is the coordinating center of the Buffalo Translational Consortium, which includes the region's premier research, educational and clinical institutions with influential community partners. The vision of the CTSI is to perform innovative clinical and translational research to reduce health disparities and improve the health of our community and the nation. We engage our community as research partners to create a shared environment to bring discoveries in the laboratory, clinic and community to benefit individual and public health.

grant_details.title: Advancing womenÃ¢ÂÂs health through research: the UNC WRHR Career Development Program
grant_details.abstract: NARRATIVE The Women’s Reproductive Health Research Career Development Program at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill (the UNC WRHR Program) supports promising obstetrician-gynecologists during an important stage in their professional advancement. The program provides the dedicated effort, mentorship, and structured career development activities needed to support their transition to research independence. UNC WRHR scholars conduct cutting-edge research to advance women’s reproductive health—domestically and globally—in a vibrant and fostering research environment.

grant_details.abstract: NARRATIVE The Women’s Reproductive Health Research Career Development Program at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill (the UNC WRHR Program) supports promising obstetrician-gynecologists during an important stage in their professional advancement. UNC WRHR scholars conduct cutting-edge research to advance women’s reproductive health—domestically and globally—in a vibrant and fostering research environment.

grant_details.title: Advancing Equity in Treatment Outcomes for Black Pregnant and Postpartum People Who Use Drugs and have Child Welfare and Criminal Legal Systems Involvement
grant_details.abstract: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it addresses the contribution of racism to racial disparities in substance use and parenting outcomes for pregnant people who use drugs. The proposed study will gather robust, nuanced data on experiences that Black people who use drugs in pregnancy and have had exposure to incarceration and child welfare agencies. The project is relevant to NIDA’s mission as stated in its Racial Equity Initiative because it seeks to understand and develop strategies to improve the how two systems entrenched in structural racism-- incarceration and child welfare systems-- impact substance use treatment and parenting outcomes for an overlooked and marginalized group of individuals.

grant_details.title: LARC Use in Females
grant_details.abstract: NARRATIVE This innovative project will investigate the feasibility of developing and administering peer-based narratives to increase the use of highly reliable contraceptives among teenagers. Using narratives to increase contraceptive use among teenagers has great potential since contraceptive decision making is based on peer influence. This project will create an electronic file that can easily be viewed on electronic tablets and web-based applications; thus, its potential to prevent teen pregnancies is far reaching.

grant_details.title: Mid Career Award in Patient Oriented Pelvic Floor Research
grant_details.abstract: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: As the population ages, women with pelvic floor disorders will be seeking treatment in increasing numbers. Level 1 randomized trial data is important in determining the strength of treatment approaches to pelvic floor disorders in an unbiased manner; there is a dearth of this type of data in the literature. This project provides support to an investigator committed to pursuing robust research initiatives in women with pelvic floor disorders and to mentor the clinicians and researchers of the future.           PROJECT NARRATIVE  As the population ages, women with pelvic floor disorders will be seeking treatment in increasing numbers. grant_details.title: Molecular and neuro-inflammatory biology of aging bladder in normal and disease states
grant_details.abstract: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bladder infections and associated lower urinary tract symptoms affects millions of individuals in the US. The goals of this Research Center are to use mouse models and human patient samples to understand these diseases, enhance the quality of bladder research, and attract new talent to the study of bladder diseases. In the long term, work from this Center will lead to new markers to assess bladder health in patients and design optimized treatment strategies.

grant_details.title: UCSF Environmental Research and Translation for Health Center (EaRTH Center)
grant_details.abstract: The overall goal of the proposed UCSF Environmental Research and Translation for Health Center (EaRTH Center) is to accelerate the pace of recognizing and preventing environmental exposures that affect reproduction and development, to improve health across the lifespan. We will offer focused resources to provide expertise and state-of-the-art technologies to create and support new research directions in environmental health at UCSF that are not currently possible. Our research will be tightly integrated with our community engagement, which will embed environmental health within the health care community. Our integrated Center will lead to new scientific understandings in environmental health, which will shift the fundamental understanding of the role of environment in disease, leading to solutions to preventing harmful exposures and improving health.

grant_details.title: Improving Health Outcomes and Equity by Targeting Postpartum Mothers at Highest Risk
grant_details.abstract: Growing attention has focused on the postpartum period as an important window to address maternal mortality disparities as half of pregnancy-related deaths occur postpartum, and Black and Latina women's excess burden of mortality and morbidity continues during this period. Black and Latina women experience more postpartum complications, ED visits, and postpartum readmissions than do White women. Our mixed method study uses an ecosocial framework to better identify Black and Latina women most at risk for poor outcomes following childbirth, the problems they experience, and to adapt an evidence-based intervention that aims to improve quality of postpartum care for high risk women.

grant_details.title: An integrated exercise and bladder training intervention to reduce falls in older women with urinary incontinence
grant_details.abstract: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it seeks to establish the efficacy of an innovative and scalable intervention to addresses two prevalent and debilitating conditions, falls and urinary incontinence, which together affect 1 in 2 older adult women. Successful completion of this project has the potential to significantly decrease the substantial morbidity that results from these two conditions in community-dwelling women and thus is relevant to the NIH’s mission to enhance health and reduce disability.

grant_details.title: CommunityRx for Hunger - Resubmission 01
grant_details.abstract: PROJECT NARRATIVE Food insecurity is a prevalent and modifiable, but largely overlooked, determinant of health and health disparities. Our objective is to improve self- and family management among food insecure caregivers of ill children by intervening at the critical time of the child’s hospital discharge. The long-term goal of this mixed-methods work advances the public health mission of NIH by promoting the health of caregivers and their families and reducing health disparities due to socioeconomic disadvantage.

grant_details.title: A stigma responsive service delivery model for HPV-based screening among women living with HIV
grant_details.abstract: NARRATIVE HIV, cervical cancer and human papillomavirus (HPV) are interrelated health conditions with intersecting stigmas that may influence women’s uptake of prevention services. We will evaluate the effectiveness of a novel stigma-responsive service delivery model for HPV-based cervical cancer screening called “Elimisha HPV” among women in a high HIV-prevalence area of Kenya. If effective, this may serve as a new model for cervical cancer screening as well as a new paradigm for comprehensive, stigma-responsive service delivery packages for people living with HIV.

grant_details.title: University of Puerto Rico Mentoring Institute for HIV and Mental Health Research: Developmental, competency-based research mentoring for junior investigators.
grant_details.abstract: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE    Project Narrative Social and behavioral research is needed to increase the understanding of how to end the HIV/AIDS epidemic. This project will train a group of junior researchers so that they can explore the multiple factors that affect the people living with HIV and their quality of lfe. It also aims to promote research that could be used to understand how to reduce the number of people getting infected and increase the number of HIV + persons in care.

grant_details.title: The CIDRZ-UNZA eLearning Platform for Research Training
grant_details.abstract: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: We seek to develop the technological framework and technical expertise to implement locally relevant curricula for research training in Zambia. We will apply the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill's experience in distance education and course development, and transfer this capacity to the Centre for Infectious Disease Research in Zambia (CIDRZ) and the University of Zambia (UNZA) over the three-year award. Upon this foundation, we will develop and administer an intensive training curriculum in applied public health informatics, one that addresses a critical gap in research and program implementation in Africa.

grant_details.title: MOthers' AdvocateS In the Community for Mothers with Experience of intimate partner violence
grant_details.abstract: PROJECT NARRATIVE IPV is a global public health concern affecting millions of reproductive age women worldwide. Pregnant women and mothers with children under 5 who IPV often experience elevated depressive and PTSD symptoms. This study will develop and pilot test of a mentor mother intervention to reduce symptoms of maternal depression and PTSD and prevent subsequent IPV.

grant_details.title: Peer navigation for individuals with serious mental illness leaving jail
grant_details.abstract: PROJECT NARRATIVE Serious mental illness (SMI) is a burdensome and widely prevalent public health problem among incarcerated men and women. Incarcerated individuals with SMI re-entering the community after jail stay experience the double stigma of criminal justice involvement and having the diagnosis of SMI, therefore, are likely to disengage with community level mental health, medical care and substance use services at re-entry. This study proposes the development and pilot test of peer navigation intervention to increase linkages to community level mental health, medical care and substance use services.

grant_details.title: Short-Term Training for Medical Students in Cardiovascular and Pulmonary Research
grant_details.abstract: The purpose of this T35 grant renewal is to provide intensive, short-term (2.5 months) research training for 20 medical students who will conduct clinical, translational, and basic research projects that are relevant to the mission of the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute with focus on cardiovascular and pulmonary topics. Research will be conducted under mentorship of faculty members from the colleges of medicine, engineering, veterinary medicine, and pharmacy who have a proven record of research and training of pre-doctoral and post-doctoral medical and graduate students. The program is designed to attract the most highly qualified University of Florida medical students into careers as physician-scientists in heart, lung, and blood areas.

grant_details.title: RCMI Biannual Intl Health Disparities Symposium
grant_details.abstract: The objective of the symposium is to create a forum for intellectual exchange,  collaborative interactions within and beyond the RCMI Institutions, and share new and  innovative approaches toward eliminating health disparities. The symposium agenda will  include invited keynote/plenary lectures by nationally recognized scholars, oral and  poster presentations by RCMI investigators and technical workshops.

grant_details.title: Epigenetic Regulation in High-Risk Leukemia
grant_details.abstract: NARRATIVE This award will develop the fellowship applicant's fundamental knowledge, conceptual frameworks, research expertise, and professional skills to maximize his impact as a physician-scientist. Research performed by the applicant under this award is aimed at defining the molecular mechanisms by which leukemia develops and identifying combinations of drugs that can target these mechanisms to effectively treat a very deadly form of leukemia. !

grant_details.title: Teacher-Child Interaction Training: A Classroom-Based Preschool Intervention
grant_details.abstract: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: The Teacher-Child Interaction Training Preschool Program (TCIT-PRE) was created to provide Head Start teachers with effective strategies/skills to better understand and address challenging classroom issues, thereby promoting the social, emotional, and behavioral development of Head Start children. Further, since critical shortages of teachers available to work with young children with social, emotional, and behavioral problems exists (Klein & Gilkerson, 2000), understanding the impact of TCIT-PRE on Head Start teachers' perceptions of efficacy and satisfaction will have practical utility for Head Start management striving to retain highly qualified educators. Moreover, findings from this study will have widespread research, practice, and policy implications for Head Start administration (and the early childhood scientific community) regarding the efficacy of a widely applicable and easily disseminated intervention in reducing a broad spectrum of problems in ...

grant_details.title: Novel quantitative proteomic approaches to define the altered interplay between OGlcNAcylation and Phosphorylation in myofilament dysfunction of diabetic hearts
grant_details.abstract: Project Narrative  Diabetic cardiomyopathy is present in 60% of diabetic patients, and no therapy is currently available to halt or significantly alter the course of this disease. This proposal seeks to use proteomics and physiological techniques to identify the mechanisms by which diabetes weakens the molecular motor proteins of the heart. Advances in this field can potentially generate early diagnostic tools for diabetic cardiomyopathy and open new therapeutic venues to fix the molecular motors of a failing diabetic heart.

grant_details.title: A Pipeline for Research, Education and Mentoring in Reproductive Aging
grant_details.abstract: NARRATIVE Aging of the reproductive tissues increases susceptibility to numerous age-related comorbidities and mortality and thus has relevance well beyond implications for procreation. While numerous advances have been made in studying organismal aging, the area of reproductive aging has not received adequate attention for education, research and discovery, especially at an institutional level. This application proposes to create an educational, research and mentoring program focused on reproductive aging to establish it as an institutional goal at the University of Pittsburgh and beyond.

grant_details.title: Exosomal-mediated pyroptosis in ventilation-associated preterm brain injury
grant_details.abstract: PROJECT NARRATIVE Preterm infants who are mechanically ventilated face increased risk of developing brain injury and neurodevelopmental problems, but we do not understand the link between mechanical ventilation and increased risk of brain injury in preterm newborns. The goal of this proposal is to test the hypothesis that mechanical ventilation causes pulmonary cells to release vesicles that penetrate the brain and induce brain cell death. If we can understand what is causing brain cell death in mechanically ventilated preterm newborns, we may be able to develop therapeutic strategies to improve the neurodevelopmental outcomes of these vulnerable infants.

grant_details.title: Treatment Modifications, Outcomes and Provider Decision Making in the Management of Subsequent Breast Cancers Among Survivors of Childhood Cancer
grant_details.abstract: Project Narrative The number of childhood cancer survivors is rapidly increasing in the United States and they face multiple late health complications of therapy, including subsequent cancers. Female survivors are at increased risk for subsequent breast cancer and although prescribed treatment is often limited by previous childhood cancer treatment exposures, no standards of care exist for appropriate modifications. By studying how breast cancer among female survivors is treated, how treatment is tolerated and how survival compares to population breast cancer outcomes, this project will contribute to enhancing health and potentially decreasing morbidity and mortality among this high-risk survivor population.

grant_details.title: Exosomal-mediated pyroptosis in ventilation-associated preterm brain injury
grant_details.abstract: PROJECT NARRATIVE Preterm infants who are mechanically ventilated face increased risk of developing brain injury and neurodevelopmental problems, but we do not understand the link between mechanical ventilation and increased risk of brain injury in preterm newborns. The goal of this proposal is to test the hypothesis that mechanical ventilation causes pulmonary cells to release vesicles that penetrate the brain and induce brain cell death. If we can understand what is causing brain cell death in mechanically ventilated preterm newborns, we may be able to develop therapeutic strategies to improve the neurodevelopmental outcomes of these vulnerable infants.

grant_details.title: A Genomics Approach to Gamma-Globin Regulation
grant_details.abstract: Project Narrative A complete understanding of -globin regulation is essential to the development of therapies for individuals with hemoglobinopathies. We used natural human genetic variation to two genes in a pathway, FOXO3 and AMPK, as possible positive –globin regulators. We now seek to understand how FOXO3 regulates –globin expression using genomics and molecular biology techniques in human erythroid cells.

grant_details.title: Diabetes-Docs: Physician-Scientist Career Development Program (DiabDocs)
grant_details.abstract: PROJECT NARRATIVE The prime objective of our National K12 “Diabetes-Docs: Physician-Scientist Career Development Program” (DiabDocs) is to train and foster the development of diverse physician-scientists for productive and impactful diabetes research careers with a specific focus on type 1 diabetes (T1D). Our K12 program is designed to provide: 1) a mentored research experience, 2) research project support, and 3) career development training, including directed attention to diversity, equity and inclusion. We are confident that we will attract the highest caliber of applicants and mentor them toward impactful careers in academic medicine as skilled physician-scientist leaders.

grant_details.title: Pediatric Scientist Development Program
grant_details.abstract: Project Narrative The Pediatric Scientist Development Program (PSDP) has implemented a comprehensive strategy to expand the boundaries of child health research and develop the research careers of rigorously trained, diverse pediatric physician-scientists. The PSDP seeks to produce the next generation of diverse investigative pioneers that represent diversity of patient populations, who will discover the causes and cures of childhood illness for all children. The PSDP inclusively invites and accepts scholars from multiple disciplines, backgrounds, and academic institutions; It recognizes that a diverse group of pediatrician physician-scientists is better equipped to address health issues affecting all communities and achieve maximum health impact.

grant_details.title: Pediatric Scientist Development Program
grant_details.abstract: PROJECT NARRATIVE As the percentage of children in the US population surpasses 20%, pediatric diseases such as prematurity, infections, asthma, obesity, and childhood heart disease and cancer claim an ever-greater share of the public health burden. The recognition that many adult diseases such as diabetes or mental illness have roots in childhood also creates a pressing need for investigation. The Pediatric Scientist Development Program provides pediatricians with the scientific training to discover the causes and cures of childhood illness.

grant_details.title: Novel Executive Function Training for Obesity
grant_details.abstract: PROJECT NARRATIVE Currently, the best behavioral treatments for obesity only work for 50% of adults, and of those who initially succeed, most do not maintain their weight loss. One reason for this failure may be due to neurocognitive deficits found among individuals with obesity, particularly related to executive function, which make it difficult for these adults to adhere to treatment recommendations. The proposed study aims to develop a Novel Executive Function Treatment (NEXT), which when administered prior to the behavioral treatment, could help improve outcomes by addressing the neurocognitive deficits in adults with overweight or obesity.

grant_details.title: Optimizing Patient Use of Devices and Data in Early Adolescents with Type 1 Diabetes
grant_details.abstract: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: A number of devices, such as insulin pumps and continuous glucose monitoring devices, can assist people with type 1 diabetes (T1D) in keeping track of their blood glucose levels, dosing insulin, and understanding how everyday events impact their glucose control, which ultimately keeps them at lower risk for diabetes complications. However, many patients, especially adolescents, do not independently review their own diabetes data or use advanced features of their devices. The goals of this project are to identify the features of these devices that most influence glycemic control in adolescents with T1D, to understand the barriers and facilitators of use of these device features in adolescents, and to use this information in designing and pilot testing the feasibility of a novel intervention to improve knowledge and use of diabetes devices, thus contributing to improved education and clinical outcomes in T1D.

grant_details.title: Patient-Oriented Research in Arginine Deficiency Syndromes
grant_details.abstract: Project Narrative: Pain is the hallmark of sickle cell disease (SCD), and is the leading cause of hospitalizations, emergency room visits, missed school, and is associated with an increased death rate. We found that patients with SCD and pain had low levels of the amino acid arginine in their blood, and we also demonstrated that arginine supplementation during acute pain events significantly reduced the amount of opioids needed to treat sickle cell pain in children and dramatically improved pain scores at discharge compared to placebo. We propose to investigate the benefits and safety of arginine for the treatment of patients with SCD and pain in a randomized, placebo-controlled clinical trial where neither the patient nor the clinical team know which therapy the patient is receiving, since Arginine is a promising nutritional therapy that could change the way we treat acute pain in SCD.

grant_details.title: (SCANS) Sickle Cell Anemia Neurodevelopmental Screening - Mentoring and Research in Patient Oriented Research
grant_details.abstract: Project Narrative Sickle cell disease (SCD) is an inherited hemolytic anemia associated with under-recognized developmental delay and cognitive deficits. Guidelines for preventive developmental screening have suboptimal adherence, but implementation science interventions can improve screening rates and indicated referrals for evidence- based interventions. This proposal enhances the ability to scale up screening and interventions for this high- risk and impoverished population while training future generations of clinical investigators in implementation science and hematology.

grant_details.title: Mentoring Patient Oriented Research in Allergic Eosinophilic Gastrointestinal Disorders
grant_details.abstract: Project Narrative EoE is an allergic disease of increasing prevalence that requires repeated esophageal biopsy and is treated with anti-inflammatory therapy to control the complications of esophageal rigidity, strictures, and food impactions caused by fibrosis and smooth muscle changes referred to as tissue remodeling. I have a strong foundation of mentoring trainees and conducting patient oriented research (POR). I proposes to integrate funded research and strong pool of junior investigators from multiple disciplines to become an outstanding POR mentor and expand my current EoE remodeling research to unanswered questions of how a rigid matrix alters structural cell function, gender differences, and mechanisms of epithelial barrier dysfunction in EoE.

We found that patients with SCD and pain had low levels of the amino acid arginine in their blood, and we also demonstrated that arginine supplementation during acute pain events significantly reduced the amount of narcotics needed to treat sickle cell pain in children and dramatically improved pain scores at discharge compared to placebo. We propose to investigate the benefits and safety of arginine for the treatment of patients with SCD and pain in a randomized, placebo-controlled clinical trial where neither the patient nor the clinical team know which therapy the patient is receiving, since Arginine is a promising new therapy that could change the way we treat acute pain in SCD.

grant_details.title: (SCANS) Sickle Cell Anemia Neurodevelopmental Screening - Mentoring and Research in Patient Oriented Research
grant_details.abstract: Project Narrative Sickle cell disease (SCD) is an inherited hemolytic anemia associated with under-recognized developmental delay and cognitive deficits. Guidelines for preventive developmental screening have suboptimal adherence, but implementation science interventions can improve screening rates and indicated referrals for evidence- based interventions. This proposal enhances the ability to scale up screening and interventions for this high- risk and impoverished population while training future generations of clinical investigators in implementation science and hematology.

grant_details.title: Mentoring Patient Oriented Research in Allergic Eosinophilic Gastrointestinal Disorders
grant_details.abstract: Project Narrative EoE is an allergic disease of increasing prevalence that requires repeated esophageal biopsy and is treated with anti-inflammatory therapy to control the complications of esophageal rigidity, strictures, and food impactions caused by fibrosis and smooth muscle changes referred to as tissue remodeling. I have a strong foundation of mentoring trainees and conducting patient oriented research (POR). I proposes to integrate funded research and strong pool of junior investigators from multiple disciplines to become an outstanding POR mentor and expand my current EoE remodeling research to unanswered questions of how a rigid matrix alters structural cell function, gender differences, and mechanisms of epithelial barrier dysfunction in EoE.

grant_details.title: Mentoring and patient-oriented research in malaria
grant_details.abstract: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: This grant is designed to support mentorship of the next generation of translational, patient-oriented malaria researchers in the United States and Malawi and also to allow the applicant to acquire new skills and knowledge to expand her research capacity. With the benefit of this training and support, the applicant and her trainees will develo new strategies to help prevent, treat and eventually eradicate malaria.

grant_details.title: Patient Oriented Research in Vitamin D Deficiency in CKD
grant_details.abstract: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) affects more than 10 million Americans and poses an enormous financial burden on the US health care system; therefore, strategies for the prevention and treatment of CKD complications are vitally important. Dr. Leonard proposes to renew her K24 funding to continue her productive mentorship of junior clinical investigators in studies related to CKD and its complications. The research aims in this application expand on her research in vitamin D metabolism in CKD to address the role of vitamin D deficiency in the progression of renal injury in CKD.

grant_details.title: Patient Oriented Research in Vitamin D Deficiency in CKD
grant_details.abstract: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) affects more than 10 million Americans and poses an enormous financial burden on the US health care system; therefore, strategies for the prevention and treatment of CKD complications are vitally important. Dr. Leonard proposes to renew her K24 funding to continue her productive mentorship of junior clinical investigators in studies related to CKD and its complications. The research aims in this application expand on her research in vitamin D metabolism in CKD to address the role of vitamin D deficiency in the progression of renal injury in CKD.
